content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the Secretary of the Air Force's direction. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol. The Civil Air Patrol is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the Secretary of the Air Force's direction. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors composed of general officers, senior civilian employees, and volunteer members. The chairman is the senior active duty Air Force officer, and volunteer members may not exceed a minority of the Board. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These appointees report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to the organization. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General of the Civil Air Patrol report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of military or civilian personnel is not restricted by laws prohibiting their involvement in non-Federal entity management. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors of the Civil Air Patrol can utilize employees and volunteer members as needed to support the noncombat mission of the Department of the Air Force.
